greeting card
[IMAGE:  lantern with lit candle hanging from snow-covered evergreen branch]]
Seasons Greetings..and Best Wishes for The New Year   College of Arts and Sciences University of Louisville
Come see our new house (rented)
Dear Jack

   I am a bastard but I'm doing Will's Book for the underlined:  Courier and sending it to Hayden.
   For Christmas' sake take one of those advances - I hope the novel one.  I want to read another book of yours.
   Our love to you and Gladys and the other Conroys.  

Harvey
Completed

greeting card   File:Two children pulling a red sled
Dear Jack and Gladys.  Well, we love you all even though we doesn't write much or very plain.  If we get Eisenhower back, I'm going to propose that he get an Einsteinium scientist to plan Green St.,  Chicago and
Completed

greeting card  Greetings AND GOOD CHEER FOR Christmas AND THE NEW YEAR
Newby Rd. Louisville side by side.  If he doesn't do that I'm going to vote against his fourth term.

  I've taken the advice of your pamphlets  (and Lucille too).  We feel worse already.  Love to all, even Nelson.

Harvey
Completed

letterhead  File:Helmeted head surrounded by UNIVERSITY OF LOUISVILLE 1798
UNIVERSITY OF LOUISVILLE   LOUISVILLE, KENTUCKY  40208     COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCES   DEPARTMENT OF ENGLISH
Dear Dr. Conroy,

      I'm afraid I'm only a professor-emeritus living in exile in Austin (a comely warm town).  I was delighted by your letter in spite of the bad news about Gladys' and your health (since rectified, I trust).  I heard also of Bud's death, and ...  It seems as though we're hit pretty hard at our age.  But the alternative I don't anticipate.
    I delighted in your reviews and parts of the autobiography which brought back fond memories of my first visit to Moberly - a mere critic taken as friend by the author of underlined: the Disinherited and underlined:  A World to Win.  And now as still I do in spite of disaster.
    I'm getting in touch with David Ray.  The issue on Conroy I've not read but he must have it with him.  Take care, you 2.  Maybe we'll see you in Moberly - or you here - before Sugar Creek.  We're for medical study or cremation - postponed as long as possible 

Love, Harvey and Lucille
Completed

written in red:  note new address

137, 1009 So. Congress  Austin, Texas, 78704
Dear Jack, 

     My long delay in answering you and thanking you for underlined:  Writers in Revolt and condoling with you about your daughter was due to our moving to Texas, perhaps permanently, partly because of Lucille's emphysema, partly because all of C.P. Snow's manuscripts are her and I'm doing a book on him.  Moving is hell at any age (I'm 70 in November, Lucille 68), heller at ours.   But we have a good apartment we can afford even if I don't teach, an apartment that's not straightened out yet.  A few days ago your underlined:  Writer in Revolt showed  up and I read it.  Apart from its bringing back the days of Will Wharton, Emmie (?) Price, Balch and others I'd known, it gives an unusually broid [sic] overview of the periods' writers, all of whom show what the period was like and may become again.  I enjoyed reading it & was pleasantly glad to find the stories as good as I remembered them (Lucille )
    I'm sorry it didn't come to me for review (Granville Hicks' criticism in the underlined:  New Mosaic I reviewed in the Louisville underlined:  Courier Journal) and that it hasn't received the good 

(over)
Completed

in pencil in bottom margin   [1977?] 
and many reviews it should have.  I hope you get more support for your autobiography and I look forward to reading underlined:  and reviewing it (surely in the Louisville [[underlined:  C-J, possibly in a media that spreads the word farther).  Anyhow I thought some pieces outstanding your story, most of the prose, some of the poetry.  All of it, ? truthful or well-written truthful, gives, as you say in your introduction a picture of a period which was more vivid and hopeful than any I've lived through since.   (But I'll vote for Jimmy Carter, hoping he's the things he says he is at least in part.)

    Your picture on the dust jacket makes you look wild and lively as I hope you still are.  Also I hope you're adquately incomed.
     I'd like to come to Moberly again as I did when you became the first good writer I knew in 1936.  so would Lucille, though her emphysema has to improve some before we can.
     I'm sorry about your daughter.  Much love to you and Gladys.

Harvey 
in right margin  Let's keep in touch.   I'll be better next time.
Completed

address label  HARVEY CURTIS WEBSTER   Spickert Knob Rd. - Route #1  FLOYD KNOBS, INDIANA
Dear Jack, dear Gladys:

       How horrifying that the Conroys have lost their folly.  And what folly to make it a place for patient patient visitors to park.  Ah, it was good in the days when impatient not-quite patients displayed their folly happily for good, sweet, lovable Jack and he foresuffered and sometimes after - suffered all -- to say nothing of tolerant, sweet, good, lovely Gladys who had her share  of fore - and  - after sufferings and joy.  Your brightnesses will never leak away as long, and may it be very long, as we both avoid our only Maker and Begetter.
      With us not much new, though there may be next year as I've an offer to teach the English novel contemporary at he University of Leeds.  But there are slips even when the cup is between the lips.
       Lucille teaches freshmen at U of L and U of Indiana (Jeffersmith), half time at each.  I create writers in default of creating myself.  Four poets a versifier out or to come out in various  magazines, including one out in Dec. Attention by Exta Williams Walking.  One novel sure of publication, three others probably to be published.  And I teach poetry to sophomores, juniors, seniors, grads and friends (or try to).  My book on English Novel since 1914 200 pgs. finished, not quite half.  Reviews all I consistently have time for.

(over)
Completed

Where we are very sylvan.  Chipmunks, cats, and some kinds of woodpeckers around our door.  Not unhappy middle-age we are.
    There'll be a time - I hope soon - when the underlined:  Disinherited will be published.  Maybe ? book will stimulate 30s interest.  I hope so.  Lots of better by far books than        Kerouac], Ginsburg, with their excreta and semen all over pages spilled underlined:  so spontaneously.
     Our Merries and Happies to you both and we must see here or there.   You're always welcome when you want to make the great trek.

Our always love,
Harvey
Completed

in pencil in top margin with line pointing to The Disinherited please return
704 So College St.
Fort Collins, Colorado,
Nov. 4, 1935.
Dear Conroy:

     I have been delayed in answering your letter by difficulties encountered in getting underlined:  The Disinherited.  I don't know how much you know about the proletariat in the West, but to this observer, anhow [sic], it doesn't seem very conscious so far.  That's why I had difficulties finding underlined: the copy in Denver
     The radical movement appears to center around the proprietor of the Bookery there.  He's a nice guy, Rosenfeld by name, and does real service for the movement.  Everytime you go there the place is pleasantly lousey with communists or almost communists like myself, cussing and discussing the latest radical book, Robert Forsythe's latest in the underlined:  New Masses or recounting personal experiences with the radical movement elsewhere.  Elsewhere seems to be the trouble, for it is a distinctly small group in Denver and doesn't appear to have very definite alignments with the workers.  I'll admit that's difficult out here.  The average farmer or beet-worker damns  the drought rather than the system.  They've taken the punches that come their way rather complacently and don't seem to have been pinched as often as the workers farther east or west.  But Rosenfeld gets in a great many left-wing books, sponsors a lending library that contains most of the late ones, and shows Robert Forsythe's articles to everyone who comes in the store.  I understand he contributes generously to recent things that come along, too.  I interested him in the underlined:  Anvil and he says he'll be glad to sell as many copies as he can.  I'm sure he will sell quite a number, if you send them to him.
   Despite the underlined:  New Republic etc.,  I like your underlined:  World to Win better than the underlined:  Disinherited, which I nevertheless regard as damn well deserving the Guggenheim.  I'm surprised, frankly, they showed good enough sense to give it  you.  underlined:  The Disinherited is probably a more evenly good book than your last.  It never lets me down very much, and it certainly contains a vast amount of material on the situation today presented with amazing succinctness.  Some of the scenes are unforgettable.  You gave me a bad hour t'other  day while I
Completed

2300 Newbury Rd
Louisville, Ky.  
Nov. 7, 1954
Dear Jack, 

     Really the only reason I've not written you in the past how many years is that I thought to shock after not having written for how too many years would be too great.  Well, that's a lie -- I'm neurotic and lazy and sometimes even commendably busy.
  You've probably heard from Stan Whitmore, whose first novel, underlined:  Solo, I like a lot, that I'm working with Granville Hicks on a book about British fiction since the 30s.  I keep puttering away my time and energy in foolishness and occasional pieces (SRL, NR, NL, etc.) but I think I'm getting squared away and will really get a lot done during the next possible years.
  I think maybe you could get  back to Yaddo.  Granville knows nothing against it and
Completed

Elizabeth loves you (though she says you haven't always as respectable as Capote and often were as disreputable acting as Harvey Webster).

    I want to see you get onto a novel and you want to see me get onto a novel  or something and even if we never do we're good guys and love one another.
    My best to Gladys, Nelson, any remembering others.
    Come see  us.

Harvey.

  Most recent likings Cowley's [[underlined:  Literary Situation],   Cummings' underlined:  Poems,  Wright Morris's  novels.
  Lucille joins in sending love.
Completed

postcard  in pencil at top:  Webster, Harvey Curtis  postmark  LOUISVILLE  KY.  JUN 21  1958  9 PM
2300 Newbey Rd.
Louisville 5,  Ky.
Jack Conroy
6912 Green St.
Chicago 21, Ill.
Completed

Dear Jack:  Hope a card's better than my usual nothing.  We're in the throes of moving cross the river to Knot Hills, Indiana, then to the wilds of Lucille's family's farm for the summer (℅ Walter S. Jones, Lovington, Ill).  Liked your review of Geisman but couldn't like a book where I'm made out a new critic (Association:  New Critics like Bellow:  Webster does: therefore).  And very pleased by your article on Frontier Humor.  Have a part of a chapter on CP Snow coming out in underlined:  Sat Rev soon.  Writing right now on Rose Macauley, good and too much neglected.  Our love to you and Gladys - love to Nelson, Harvey
Completed

New address.  'Cross the river and 'mong the trees.   Spickert Knob Road  Route 1  Floyd Knobs, Indiana  
Aug 30, 1958
Dear Jack:

    This summer I've found myself no place further than Sullivan 16 miles away  It's been my longest stint sticking to a desk, and in this weather often no metaphor.  Done up, old critic style, Ivy Compton-Burnett, Graham Greene, Rose Macaulay, Evelyn Waugh.  Maybe you saw my C. P. Snow in the underlined:  Saturday Review, July 9.  Pretty badly cut up but Snow liked and a lot of other letters underlined:  saying so.  I just sent my A. Huxley chapter to the,.  Now on to teach, not so gladly, and, as I can, to continue with ______,  _______,  and God knows how too many others.
    Sorry about your son-in-law.  Apart from the sadness it must be a strain on you and on Gladys.
    Haven't seen anything of Nelson's because I don't get the underlined:  Trib or underlined:  Nation.   Me I read the underlined:  New Statesman and the underlined:  SR's I'm in.  Is Nelson out to become bad-boy critic of bad boys or what?
    New critic, to me most of the time,  is a bad name, though the bastards are elegantly intelligent
Completed

postcard   postmark  LYMINGTON HANTS  JUNE 1963
H C Webster  Passford House   No Lymington, Hants.  England
Jack Conroy
14626 Millard Ave.
Midlothian, Illinois
U.S.A.

Dear Jack-o and Gladys-No:

     Good is it from you to nair heard, bad to have waylaid and delayed so long your letter and my now too briefly breviary amsure (How I forget sometimes to remember Moberly and you all  and the books, for Finnegan's sake, pulled down about us!).  Glad was I to receive after to Dublin going and Irish-learning Hill and Wang (Irish?)'s paperback underlined:  The Disinherited.  Have to several mistimed and wish to it and & we you long moneyed lifelike.
  underlined:  Do write your autobiography (or have you).  N.A. was nastied rather by underlined:  Time and over here, but him, Jim Liget, you all, I love in my procrasting state weigh letter writing - to.  Back with tales Sept 1.  Harvey   Book ms. end.
Completed

postcard  postmark  LOUISVILLE, KY  1A  1 30 PM  11 DEC 1963
950 So.  47th St., Louisville, Ky.  40211
Mr & Mrs. Jack Conroy 
14626 Millard Ave.
MIDLOTHIAN  ILLINOIS
SEASON'S GREETINGS
loved Norway, Denmark, Sweden in July; a mediterranean Black Sea cruise in May ("The Future" is splendid without bill-boards); Ireland, Scotland at Easter; Rome in spite of crowds last Xmas.  i go to central Illinois to my dad for Xmas & H. goes to his mother in St. Petersburg, Florida.  Hope yours is nice.  H. has been snowed under with a heavy schedule & I with one class  & a house, car & yard calling for repairs after a year's neglect.  Even one of the Siameses is deteriorating in his teeth.  Take care, Love, Lucille
Completed

postcard  postmark  LOVINGTON, ILL.  AUG 18  AM  1965
950 So. 47th St.
Louisville, Ky.
40211
Mr. & Mrs. Jack Conroy
7027 So. JEFFERY Blvd.
CHICAGO, ILLINOIS
60649
Completed

Aug. 17  How are you?  I've been loafing on the farm with my dad, who is waiting for glasses after cataract operation.   H. turned out a lot of poems 3 wks. at Yaddo, led a section of Writers Conference at Pippa Passes, Ky, & is now sweating out 5 M.A.'s.   Sept 7 we leave Louisville for 9 mo. visiting prof at Missoula, driving out with cat.  Having never seen NW we hope for some side trips as Montana U. is on quarter system.  Write 59801 zip code but skip the tracts;  H. has become a quaker.  Last 3 weeks of spring semester Harvey spent 3 wks in St. Petersburg with his mother, who died underlined: after a successful operation.  Students & registrar were hysterical.   
Love, Lucille
Completed

950 So. 47th St.
Louisville, Ky  40211
Dec. 4, [[added in pencil:  [1966]  ]]
Dears,

   What have you done, moved back to Missouri like you threatened?  Betty (the 2nd Mrs. Tom Bledsoe; there is now a 3rd) called your home a couple weeks ago for us when she was in Chi on business & was told phone had been disconnected.
   Harvey goes to N.Y.C. at Xmas for Mod. Lang. Assoc. meeting.  I'm staying home for the 1st holiday in years - my idea of the only way to take a vacation.
   We liked Alaska this summer, but got tired of roads & put ourselves & car on the really fine Canadian R.R. for faster, cheaper, more
Completed

comfortable & better way to see the scenery trip from Van Couver to N. of Rockford, where we stopped overnight with Harvey's sister.

    Harvey is swamped & looks like neither of us is going to get any Xmas cards done.  So please let this be an early Merry, etc, wishing & let us hear all you've been up to, and how your various new editions are doing.

Love, Lucille
Completed

postcard Thinking of You    File:Woman seated at writing desk with feather pen
1/1/67  We do remember well how flattered we were at your reception in Moberly in 1936, was it?  So sorry about the raw deal from the enclopedia. [sic]  Mighty glad about Swados' anthology & what a wonderful piece Petakis had in underlined:  Book News!  David Madden was here a couple years, lived in our house last time we were in England.  
different handwriting    At MLA in NYC I saw Hill and told him to treat you right.  The paper-back underlined:  Disinherited was displayed prominently and I hope doesn't have its sales hurt by the anthology (or do you get more from Swados?)  Met Stanley Burnshaw at MLA reception, last met at underlined:  NM office.  NYC makes one appreciate Moberly, even Louisville.   Best for a Hip New Year to you, Gladys.  Love, H, L
Completed

postcard  postmark  LOUISVILLE, KY  402   PM   19 DEC 1975
Webster
950 So. 47th
Louisville, Ky.  40211
Mr. & Mrs. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave.
Moberly
Missouri
65270
Completed

Dec. 18, 1975.  It seems years since we have heard from you.  We miss your religious tracts and news of how you are, how things in Moberly are these drear days, etc., etc.  H. is trying to teach just the 1st sem. & going somewhere warmer in the 2nd.  This year we plan to go Austin where U. of Texas has bought C. P. Snow's M.S.   H. is doing a book on Lord Snow, whom we met in Oxford when he did his 1st version of the 2 cultures.  How are you, what are you doing, why don't you write?  Mail will be forwarded when we go to Texas in January   H. taught the Disinherited last year with good results.  Anyhow we wish you the Joyes [sic] of the Season and a very Happy New Year.
Love, Harvey & Lucille
Completed

pencil in top margin  Webster, Harvey Curtis
postcard  File:Drawing of little boy kissing little girl
postmark   LOUISVILLE,  KY  402   5 JAN  1976
Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave.
Moberly, Mo, 65270
Completed

450 So 47th  Louisville, Ky  40211
Jan 5, 1976
Dear Jack,   It was so good to hear from you.  It makes me wonder how our correspondence stopped.   Which of us slipped or was it the mail service aggrivated [sic] by our travels.   To Europe, Africa, Australia, England, the Continent and much here.  I'm professor emeritus which means I can teach but have no vote and, praise be, no committees.  In my course on the Thirties, underlined:  The Disinherited was liked most by the good students  (underlined:  USA and underlined:  Grapes of Wrath and underlined:  The People, Yes, were among the competition.  
We're both very sorry about your daughter, glad you have so much coming out and come out.  I'm doing a book on C. P. Snow, going to Texas a week from now to work on it with Lucille (Snow's ms. there.  Where are yours?)  I'm sending you my second book which got little attention because of poor promotion.   As always, H.
I see that spirits are lowered.  Your work?
Completed

postcard  postmark  AUSTIN TX  187   1 PM   27 SEP 1977
Webster. Apt.   452
1201 South Congress
Austin, Texas
78704

Mr & Mrs Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave.  
Moberly
Missouri  65270
Completed

Sept. 24.  How are you?  We were lucky we sold our Ky. house last summer & missed the very cold winter.  We guess your winter was bad too.  Our summer has been 10º hotter ea. day than in Louisville.   H. has given himself a vacation except for waiting on me & the dog & some book reviews - one in the N. Republic, Oct. 2.  We saw a review of yours quoted in the library when we were getting our weekly quota of reading.  Love, Harvey & Lucille
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Webster, Harvey  [1979]
Dear dear Jack and Gladys,  How are  you 2?   We're still here, I've resumed my book on CP Snow, done a bunch of reviews for underlined:  NR, NL, LC-J Lucille helps me despite her painful emphysema.

  How we miss you and wish we were Moberlying right now.  J  F Powers is the only one of the old bunch apart from you that I hear from .
  We still keep your picture, Jack, properly framed.  Wish we could see you and /or get some pamphlets from you.  We still drink, don't smoke.

Love, Harvey and Lucille
Completed

postcard  postmark  LOUISVILLE KY.  JUN 29 1954  8 30 PM
Webster
2300 Newberg Rd
Louisville 5, Ky
Mr. Jack Conroy
6012 South Green ST
Chicago 21
Illinois
Completed

June 28.  Harvey had planned to go to Yaddo the end of the 1st 5 weeks of summer school which he is teaching, but I broke my ankle going out to stake the tomatoes last Wednesday & unless I get pretty agile on crutches or get some one to stay with me he sounds hesitant about leaving me.   I am supposed to learn to use crutches today, but since I've learned you can break a bone just walking along I'll be a sissy for a while.   underlined:  What review was it in the  double underlined:  Sun-Times?  H. knew nothing about it.  When you go to the Ozarks would you be any where near Louisville?  If so, stop in.   I think summer school lasts till about the last of July.   H. would be here the 10th sure.   Love Lucille
Completed

postcard  postmark LOUISVILLE KY.  3   DEC 10 1953  10 30 PM
Webster
2300 Newberg Rd.
Louisville 5, Ky
Mr. Jack Conroy
6012 So. Green St.
Chicago 21, Illinois
Completed

Dear Jack, Just run across your June 26 note again & feeling mellow with pre-holiday spirit decided you deserve at least a postal since we long ago gave up Xmas cards.  H. is teaching full time this year, glad to be rid of the directorship of audio-visual here which meant a lot of TV work & other details.  Plans to go to N.Y. Xmas & talk to Granville about a book of criticism of Br. lit. they would like to do together if they can get an advance.  Ive been teaching ½  time in the Eng. dept. this year & last.  What's new with you?  H. keeps busy with reviews & I with a litter of Siamese,  a garden & a deep freeze.  Getting domestic in my old age - even made some preserves.   We still love you & we miss your wonderful letters.   Lucille
Completed

was puzzling out who in Hell had copied the death of Rollie from you, for I was sure I had seen it elsewhere and was equally certain I hadn't read any short pieces of yours prior to 1933.  But I had and finally resurrected the death scene in underlined:  Left for 1931.  the scene had apparently impressed me more than your name.  The homecoming at Monkey's Nest, the death of Larry's father, and the scene with Helen in the whore-house were others that particularly impressed me.  I was rather sorry that you didn't do more with Helen.  My romantic soul felt damn sorry for her and I wanted Larry to take her in, but I think you knew best.  She was, I think, your best female character.  Bonny Fein comes clear when Larry sees her at his return to Monkey's Nest, but I don't feel that you realized her especially well.  There are too many unprepared for jumps in her character.  She stands out as a conceited prig at start; then she's a strong woman who is sticking by her man in the class struggle.  I see her at each stage well, but I don't see how she went from one stage to the other.  It seems to me that insufficient preparation for changes in characters is your worst fault.  Recognizing all the difficulties under which you've labored, it's understandable, but it's also remediable, think I - but maybe I'm just obtuse.  The last scene of the book, too, seems to jump too quickly toward a conversion ending.  the scene itself is fine, but how did they get there so fast?  More time spent in showing Monkey Nest developments would have helped.  Of course, the first person technique imposed some limitations upon your treatment of Monkey Nest, but conversation flash-backs might have worked.  In other words, summing up what has run on too long, I think your scenes are swell and that the way in which one grows out of another is frequently not shown as clearly as might be.

  So for my reasons for preferring underlined:  A World to Win.  The Disinherited is primarily a horizontal book; it gives a wide cross-section of American industrial life and makes me see that scene as a whole better than any other proletarian novel I've read.  But it doesn't have as much depths as underlined:  AWTW.  Your best characters, for example, are those you sketch clearly and suggestively in underlined:  TD while in underlined:  AWTW you really make most of your characters real down to their gizzards and one sees
Completed

the situations they're in in all their ramifications more clearly.  Despite underlined:  NR again, I think the style is better in underlined:  AWT  (tho it does get a bit pretty in spots) and it's certainly a better constructed novel.  You hurry toward the end too much in both books.  anyhow, I'm anxious to see your next and expect it to be even first-rater.

    I like the underlined:  Anvil and am sending a subscription to  your business manager.  Although I don't feel that even a majority of the work contained there is first-class as short-story, I feel it all is as social material.  It all should be said again and again and we can hardly hope that every time a hurrying leader or harassed intellectual writes he's going to turn out one for the ages.  The time-sated bourgeois writer doesn't.   I think Balch is going places.  This is the first story of his I've read.  Aside from the story itself, I admire his knack for catching the rhythm of their dialogue.  "A ? at Headquarters" was A1, too.   I didn't go so much for Mike Gold's story.  It takes ingenuity to string out the idea Mussolini must have bad dreams to two pages and there are nice touches, but why do it?  Also I couldn't see Algren's story.   Nice prose but it doesn't go deep enough to do much good.  The other stories were valuable for what they said, not how it was said.
   I'm glad about the Book Union, too.  I have managed to get a couple of subscribers and occasionally I manage to get some students or faculty members at Colo. State to read Strachey or Rollins or Cantwell or you.  But it's tough going here, for they're only intellectually aware, even the most intelligent of them.   They don't feel or see.  In my spare time I run a book-column for the town paper and praise, with caution I must admit, left-wing publications, but don't get many rises.  The need for caution is illustrated, perhaps, by an experience with Denver's morning paper.  They did well by me on my reviews for several  weeks, giving me a streamer across the page on a couple of books I reviewed.  But several weeks ago I sends in on my own hook a review of [[underlined:  American Writer's ? ]]. saying this is a hell of an important book, please print this review.  Since then no reviews of mine have appeared.   It may be imagination, but looks a bit like cause and effect.
Completed

I know a chap in Ann Arbor, where I taught and Ph.Ded for six years, whom you might be interested in.  He's in economics, leftish but cautious, intelligent, and has been working on employee-employer relations in the Detroit auto plants for several years.  If you feel he could be of any service to you, I'd be glad to tell him to get in touch wit you.
   I haven't had a chance at Cunningham's book.  Apparently Nathan Asch ( underlined:  NR ) doesn't agree with you.   Did you read Edward Anderson's underlined:  Hungry Men ?  I think that boy got rather a bad deal from underlined:  New Masses, just as Algren did from the underlined:  New Republic.  I don't think Algren understood the book very well when he reviewed it in underlined:  NM.  It's true that Anderson doesn't have his characters going left at the end, but are they that sort of characters and isn't it just as well that we know (so that we can combat it) that there are guys who'd prefer to play pieces before the American Legion than fight?  Besides Boots was a good communist and the reader comes from the book admiring him more than any other character.   And the characters, all of them, were alive and, no doubt, existed.
   How I rave on.
   I did appreciate your letter and hope to hear more from you, but also realize you must be even busier than I.

Best luck with everything.
Harvey Webster
Completed

3815 Warner
St. Matthews, Ky.
Jan. 25,  1949
Dear Conroys:

     Thanks for your nice Xmas  card.  Hope you will have a prosperous N. Year.
     We have a big house & yard, 2 cats & a 10 weeks old pup.  H. weighs 160 lbs & feels better than usual.
     We have 2 bedrooms & oil heat & haven't had any cold weather yet.  Maybe you ought to take your vacation in the winter.  Anyhow, do come to see us whenever you can, & keep us up on the news in between.

Best love to you all
Lucille
P.S.  Jack, are you responsible for Harvey in Who's Who in the Midwest?
Completed

postcard   [[postmark]  DURHAM  11 OCT 1950
54 Western Hill, Durham
England.  Oct. 11
We enjoyed Jack's letter which we got just before we left.   You no doubt know we are here for a yr. on a Fullbright award to Harvey.  We are especially happy with all things here not the least important of which is the non-advertizing radio with very high class programs from underlined:  Antigone to Josh White.  Glad you had a 2nd yr. at Yaddo.   Do tell us all about it & what you're doing now.  H. is introducing your books to England.  Only trouble is the difficulty of getting American books here.
Love, Lucille Webster
Mr. & Mrs. Jack Conroy
6012 Green St.,
Chicago
Illinois
U.S.A.
Completed

Dear Jack,

  Your letters are always good and I don't know quite why you have the goodness of spirit (or body) to keep sending them to such a bad correspondent as I am.  From all of them I benefit greatly and I do appreciate the tender pamphlets you send usually.  They do my heart an endless amount of good though they leave my body in about the same state since I continue to drink and smoke at a state most inappropriate to my heavenly aspirations.
    And you?  Is the Chicago water-wagon still called (with surprising suddenness for it formerly had another nomenclature ) the Wagon of Conroy?   And do you persist in the ? (of even longer standing) of underlined:  never smoking the cigarettes which descended me?
    In England we had fun, though immoderation rarely raises its vivid head as often as in Chi or NYC.  I teach students who are often workers, frequently miners, too often middle-class
Completed

housewives, as much as I can about contemporary American literature.  So far you are only on the prospectus.  I'll look to see if underlined:  The Disinherited can be bought over here.  So far the most intelligent man in England is my boss (Director of Extra-Mural Studies) who has read and remembers and likes underlined:  The Disinherited.  I hope another novel for the 2 projected will come through.  You can if you will, Jack.

   All you tell me of Nelson and the rest interests me immensely.  I do teach the underlined:  Neon Wilderness, Never Come Morning, The Man With the Golden Arm.  I mean that I will teach them in the spring term and I will of course sock class in the teeth those that do not
Completed

appreciate.

   Really, most do.  Curiously the only esoteric the English like is E. E. Cummings.   They are fond of Sandberg, A. MacLeish, etc.  In fiction I still have to find out, as I haven't taught English fiction in America, but I think they'll like what we do.
   No intelligent guy here is all out for a world-war, nor am I.  We hold the line stoically between the left and right, worrying, hoping, thinking that  sometime we'll learn the answer to the 64 00 question.
   What is never doubt is our love for you, Gladys, Bud, Nelson, and all the good guys.  If we're Atom-bombed, let it be together.  Do get your novels written and published, tho.

Harvey
Completed

letterhead   THE DURHAM COLLEGES IN THE UNIVERSITY OF DURHAM
54 Western Hill
Durham City, Eng.
February 26, 1951
Dear Jack,

     Yes, Midwest Humor did arrive and a good thing, too.  It went to the book box of my best class and has been withdrawn with delight many times - a welcome change from such somber writers as Dreiser, Anderson, Conroy, et al.  It's right nice to remember your old besotted American friend with all these books and the English do appreciate it.  By the by, though underlined:  The Disinherited is in some libraries, my bookseller hasn't tracked down that English edition.  Next time I'm in London I'll see what I can find.
    England's rather fun.  But here in the provinces I don't see
Completed

letterhead  THE DURHAM COLLEGES  IN THE UNIVERSITY OF DURHAM
many writing people, though there are some hopefuls who try and may get there.  I do see all kinds of other folk - our class, in Washington, all miners (as I told you),  otherwise I talk to and teach  housewives, teachers, factory workers, Rotarians, Fabians, United Nations Clubs, Literary Societies, etc.  They do like and read you - especially the miners.   I'm going to send you, by the way, a copy of underlined:  The Thin Seam.  I think a damn good work by a Durham miner.

    Tonight I talk to the univ. students about Whitman. 
     We keep fairish though the temperature underlined: inside is hard for
Completed

letterhead  THE DURHAM COLLEGES  IN THE UNIVERSITY OF DURHAM
an American softy to put up with and I've only had one cold since September, in fact I still have it.  But it's fun and I think I might stay another year either here or in Germany where I've a chance to do some radio work.

   On the other hand I might return, too, and it would be nice if it was to you and Chicago and Nelson and the boys.
   Give our best to Gladys.  Lucille sends love, I manly affection to  you

Harvey
Completed

Friday
Nov. 30, 1973
Dear Jack -

  I hope that all was wine and roses at the Grand Bash for Writers in Revolt at The Old Town School of Folk Music.   I will ask our librarian to buy it for the edification of the natives.
  I will send the flier about the book to Jesse Stuart in Kentucky along with the 'Sage of Moberly' article from Daily News Panorama.  Someone sent me a clipping not long ago, in which he had some kind words for you.
   I deeply regret not being able to get to Chicago for the festivities as I am awaiting a call from Vet's Hospital in Iron Mountain, Mich. for eye surgery.  Cataracts on both eyes, but can still appreciate a well turned ankle.
   I will send along a copy of the fortieth anniversary issue of Esquire magazine which may be of some, social, cultural or nostalgic interest.

Yours For The Revolution!!
Bill Wedlake
Completed

letterhead  William G. Wedlake 1438 North State Parkway, Chicago, Illinois  60610    inserted in letterhead  235 W. Bluff St  Marquette, Mich.  49855 
Thursday, May 7
Dear Jack - it is always good go hear a voice crying out of the Wilderness.   The Folk Bash at Mountain View sounds like great stuff to me.  I have long been an admirer of the virile Herr Driftwood.   I can recall a bravura number of his called "Tying Knots in the Devil's Tail."   I believe that my old friend Harold Sherman the Psychology and ESP expert occupies a chalet in the mountains there.

   I will not call Marquette a God forsaken community because there are by my count 25 churches to serve the spiritual aspirations of the citizenry and all of the most fundamental kind.   The blow that really struck me down was that I who had come here seeing only an honest occupation at my trade was told that bookstores in this land of night do not exist.   Of course such a detail as that, I living in the cloud cuckoo land of Chicago would not have checked out in advance.
    This is a sort of return to the roots for me because my father came to the copper and iron country from Cornwall, England back around the turn of the century and was involved in the bloody labor  battles of that  era here and later in the coal pits of LaSalle County, Ill. where I was born.  alas!  the only trace left of Cornish influence are the pasty shops that are slowly giving way to pizza parlors.
    Re: Stud's "Hard Times" I was delighted to note that Jimmy Sheridan has number one spot in the book.  Keep an eye peeled for Tom Colter's book of short stories "The Beach Umbrella"  from U. of Iowa Press.  Due about now.  

Tears and Lamentations
From Bill Wedlake
Northern Michigan University here may be wide open to a person of your belle-lettristic abilities.
Completed

in pencil in top margin   [1950]
letterhead  WILLIAM G. WEDLAKE   601 DEMING PLACE   CHICAGO, ILLINOIS
Columbus Hospital 2520 N. Lakeview  Chicago, Ill.
Dear Jack Conroy,

   The Age of Anxiety finally caught up with me and laid me out with a bum ticker.

However, the Genus Hobo is one of the most difficult forms of life to destroy.   Long ago in the jungle at Janesville, Wisc. a bearded old airedale strained some sterno through a sock and produced a libation called Derail   The continued use of such gentle potions has not been good for the pump.

   Prof. Walter Rideout has told me how kind and helpful you were to him during the preparation of "The Radical Novel."  I finally obtained after a long search mint copies of both "The Disinherited" and "A World to Win".   The first issue of the American Mercury that I came across in my heedless youth contained your story "Pipeline" and is now in my meager collection of Conroyana.  My weakened condition prevents further conflab

Yours for the Revolution
Bill Wedlake
Completed

DEAR JACK - THE DEMON BOOKSELLER OF WABASH AVE IS NOW RUSTICATING IN THE HINTERLAND, AND I DO MEAN HINTER!!  MANY YRS AGO YOUR MENTOR, H. L. MENCKEN WROTE A BIT CALLED "THE SAHARA OF BOZART"   THAT SHOULD HAVE BEEN WARNING ENOUGH.

235 W. BLUFF ST.

Completed

Monday
Aug. 24, 1970
Dear Jack -

  Browsing through the local library, I ran across a copy of David Madden's, Proletarian Writers of the Thirties.
   I felt several twinges of nostalgia in going through it.
  The problem that faces a young student of the period today is how to get his hands on the material of the time.
  Instances of reprint are rare and unusual as you well know.
  It took me several years to gather together the fourteen volumes of the great social Novel by Jules Romains:  Men of Good Will.  The great mass of ephemeral bits and pieces, pamphlets and magazines dissapear [sic] irretrievably down the drain of history.
  Books like your, The Disinherited and Roth's Call It Sleep have a survival value that transcends all categories.
  I was struck by your contribution to Madden's book because I had just finished reading The Rise and Fall of the Man of Letters by Gross in which he coupled Cantwell and Conroy as archetypes of their period.  Gross deals with the English belle lettrists but manages a few words for that forgotten young eccentric Christopher Caudwell.   I once possessed Illusion and Reality but now I have only a battered copy of Studies in a Dying Culture.
    The problem with literature that deals with the underdogs is that those who are
Completed

best equipped by experience to deal with it are usually inarticulate.

  The chimney sweeps of London for example never had anyone to portray them in human terms.
  The Cornish miners of the Upper Peninsula have left no record in literature of their struggles here.   I have found only one very dreary novel of that life called, The Long Winter Ends.
   Frank Mead writes from Chicago that the indomitable Jimmy Sheridan is in very poor health.  I feel a deep sense of failure and regret on my part in not keeping in closer touch with him.   Those were the golden days when he was the uncrowned king of Chicago Avenue and lent his glib vocabulary to the gatherings at Thompson's Restaurant, also known as the Maxim Gorky Park of Culture and Rest.
   I do hope that you are continuing with your memoirs.  This can be a real magnum opus so take your time and make it great.

Best Wishes
Bill Wedlake
Completed

Friday
Oct. 9,  1970
Dear Jack -

   Anathema to Norman Podwhoreyz and all of his ilk, including that organ of intellectual masturbation called Cemetery.  The only good man on the staff is Jack Richardson who should be writing plays instead of writing about them.  Poor Norman sold his soul for a cocktail at Lionel Trillings.   Include in this exile to the outer limits of oblivion that corruptor of youth Mr.  F. C. Leavis.  Do not send me any of A.B. since I have so little touch now with the world of books.  I may sojourn here in cloud cuckoo land for some time.  The brush fires are burning and at any moment the whole mass of trash may self destruct and slide into the sea.

Yours For The Permanent Revolution!!
Bill Wedlake
℅ Topliss  28 N. Curtis Ave.  Alhambra, Calif.  91801
Completed

Sunday, March 26  1972
Dear Jack -
On Monday night, here in Marquette, there will be a poetry reading at Church Theatre, by local poets.

  For the occasion I have written a poem called Homage to Kenneth Patchen.  This Sunday morning I consulted Hoffman's Little Magazine Bibliography and found that you were one of his very earliest publishers in the pages of The Rebel Poet.
   I then checked the Conroy issue of The American Book Collector and note that in 1969 you had written an article called, Homage to Kenneth Patchen.
   I missed seeing any account of Patchen's death and know of it only by hearsay.  I once had a fine collection of his work, picked up mostly at remainder sales.  I searched for a long time to find his first published book; Before the Brave.  Now the only scrap I have left is the Poems of Humor and Protest published by City Lights.
   My bit of doggerel, which I have enclosed, closes with the theft from three sources.  The fourth and third lines from the end are taken from W. H. Auden's Elegy on W. B. Yeats.  The next to the last line is lifted from Henry Miller's pamphlet; Patchen:  Man of Anger
Completed

and Light.  The concluding line is taken from Dylan Thomas'  poem on the death of his father.

    I have discovered an odd book on my shelves called, Battle Hymns of Toil by Covington Hall.   I will send it on to you for your library of proletarian curiosa.
    Tonight I will hold the first planning session for a production of Diary of Adam and Eve based on the Mark Twain stories that I hope to present in late May.

Excelsior!!
Bill Wedlake
Completed

Homage to Kenneth Patchen
Born - Niles, Ohio - 1911
Died      Jan. 1972
Kenneth, you've travelled many miles
Since first you saw the light in Niles.
And felt the steel mills burning breath
And turned to thoughts of life and death.
Weaving your poems in rich store
To show the ghastliness of war
And sometimes gentle as a dove
To sing the praise of joy and love.
Though mocked by critics from the schools
You didn't need that pack of fools.
Your fellow poets knew your worth
And common folk from all the earth.  
Your broken body was so strong
It fought to live to sing your songs
With spirit like a flag unfurled
Hope for a new and better world.
Kenneth Patchen has gone to rest.
Man of anger, man of light
Do not go gentle into that good night.
Bill Wedlake
Completed

April 27, 1973
Dear Jack -

   A long time ago I promised to find a copy of Murray Kempton's sophomoric diatribe.
   Here it is at last; not a very good copy but at least intact.
   These here north woods are what your mentor, Henry Louis Mencken referred to as the Sahara of Bozart, so that it was by some gracious dispensation of the heavenly powers that I found it.
   Aldous Huxley, alway [sic] a good man with a felicitous phrase, once called this kind of book, "A curious essay in destructive hagiography."

Showers of Blessings on you and all your kin
Bill Wedlake
Completed

Wed. Oct. 7, 1973
Dear Jack-

    The Ozark mag may be coals to Newcastle but here it is anyway.
     Black World has notes on that late, great gentleman Arna Bontemps.
    Here in the outer limits of Limbo I am often unaware of that great big world out there.
    The Grim Reaper has gathered so many in recent days, Edmund Wilson, Conrad Aiken, W. H. Auden, Noel Coward, August Derleth, ------------ .
    The issue of 'New Letters' that you sent some time back was loaded (fraught) with items of interest.  I had our local library buy Gwen Brooks report from Part One.  Cyrus Colter is building a solid, secure body of work.
    I am also going to include the British Books and Bookmen because it has so many and varied reviews.

Best Wishes
Bill Wedlake
Completed

Wed. - July 4th/62 - a.m.
Dear Jack -

    I hope you can "dig" my scrawl.  It's so early - and a holiday - I hate to waken sleeping neighbors by typing.
    Hope you and Gladys had wonderful time underlined:  (are having. since you're still there) in Moberly.
    I'll get in touch with Mary Heller - though my time seems so "pressured--" for - as you may know, I'm doing a nonfiction children's book (papercover) for Collier Bks - and the part of advance given me, already spent, so I'm doing odd jobs also to keep afloat (& so much research for book!) -
   Despite that just finished a 5,000 word story - haven't had underlined: that compulsion for ages - I underlined:  had to do it.  My agent phoned yesterday - is enthused after reading it.  All we pray is that some mag. is!  But stories are harder than ever to publish.
   And I want to get back to my play someday - a novel - do --underlined:  more

(over)
Completed

stories.  Must be "heat wave"!

   Ah for more energy - time- money -
   How greedy I be.  And there are the poems I always do -
   Today, a Welsh painter comes for dinner.  I see no one in ages - then try to get some conviviality back into living.   Martha Foley phoned me yesterday - occasionally we get pleasantly "crocked" together.  I like Martha so much.
    Don Roscher wrote of you -
    I do hope all is well with you and Gladys and all your family -

affectionately -  Henrietta  (Love to Gladys)

  Langston Hughes - whom I don't know - is running a column now in the N.Y. Post.

(over)
Completed

will be in it.  I arranged his meeting with the producers, etc.

   Despite all this, I am still a pauper - my lawyer (who is also Saul Bellows' lawyer) having to fight theirs for fair terms, so money is held up.
   Mary Ann has today off - and we meet soon - to go to the Shakespeare festival in Conn.  ( underlined:  King Lear with Morris Carnovsky). 
   I'd been away briefly - was glad to get home.  Am tired - perhaps if things go with the play, I can
Completed

2
have a real holiday - it has been underlined:  so long...

   I'll try to see your friend if she calls - needless to say, things are hectic, and I have to be available for rewrites, etc.
   Fiction seems peaceful after the storms of the chaotic theater world - but there are exciting aspects, too - of course.

May 2, 1966  Mon.
Dear Jack -

    You'd hardly believe it is spring in N.Y.   The crossed out:  April weather still lingers in April - chill, damp, dreary.  but I hope when you come on the 14th,  the sun will be shining. 
     I'd phoned Hill & Wang a short time before your current card came - the secretary to whom I spoke then had no idea underlined:  when you'd be in N.Y.
     Does your book come out May 4th or June 4?  Tony F. and I spoke on phone yesterday, and puzzled over this.
     Mary Ann, alas, is off to Europe on May 10th - on a 3-week holiday from her job at Pfizer's.   She's sorry not to be here when you arrive, but perhaps if you stay longer, you'll see each other when she's back June 1.
     Griggy (rehearsing for a new off-B'way play) was here Friday with all his family.
     Yes, I know Helene Mullins well (she's Mrs. Linné Johnson) and told her of your coming, etc.  She still lives across the street at 234 .   (over)
Completed

Does the [[underlined:  Chicago Sun-Times] publish poetry?   I am possessed with making poems - and would send them some.  But you can tell me when I see  you.  I'm having a poem published - any day now - in a underlined:  Cats magazine!  (pub. in Pittsburgh - I got a check for $1.60 for it - but their enthusiasm for my cat poem made me feel rich).
    I do hope your book goes wonderfully well - this does seem the ripe - right - time for it!   Interesting about your planning perhaps to return to Moberly to live!  Ah - these huge cities are hell - like Chicago & N.Y.
    Love to Gladys - and all good great luck!  

Affectionately -

A.M. Sat. - Aug. 13, 1966
Dear Jack -

    Your book came yesterday.  Thanks so much!
    I look forward to reading it.
    Tried to reach Arno Bontemps, but no luck.  Guess he's busy, etc.
    Beautiful early Sat. - when only a cat across yard cleaning on paws) looking out window - and I seem to be awake, sharing the sweet morning.
    So much to do ( duties, alas!) - want to get them out of way, so I can enjoy just being, and return to the forrest of self.
    The weekend passes so underlined:  fast!  I try to hang on to its coattails - but a wind blows it past and leaves me stranded once again on the rush of week.
    Good luck!  Thanks - dear Jack - again - I hope your book goes over great.   Love to Gladys.

Affectionately - Henrietta

Dear Jack -

     Many thanks for sending the reprint on your "Home...."
     I enjoyed it so much - and look forward to reading underlined:  more - probably to be your autobiography, reminiscences or whatever you'll decide to call "Remembrance of Things Past..."
   I do hope Gladys and you are well - that you keep cool in Moberly - and content.
   N.Y. is hellishly hot - humid - crowded - Oh how I yearn for sight of sea - for places that perhaps no longer exist -
Completed

2.

  Apart from reading my poems (taped in advance) on WBAI twice in April - and once on their West Coast station (KPFA) in May - things seem suspended - as do I.
  I could say this has been my "season in hell."
  A sore (left) foot sent me to a series of drs. - none of whom thought of x-raying it.  Finally, one did - and frightened me into seeing a specialist.  More x-rays and blood tests showed a disintegrating bone.  The foot - like a wing - is most complicated - and an operation not advisable
Completed

3.

   So I wear a brace ( I hope underlined: not forever!) to be able to walk yet rest the weary bone (immobilize it, leaving the rest of foot and leg mobile).
   It is light-aluminum, but the shoe is heavy - especially in summer and for managing the top floor.
   So I'm trying to move.  Apts. are so costly around here, not much luck finding any decent place so far.   The apt. here  (under uninsulated roof) is  hot - the fan hardly helping.
   Oh - enough of complaints.  Were I rich,
Completed

4.
this would be a good time to dive into real writing again, but problems distract - get between me and the too-soon flown visions.

   Good luck to you  - Jack - good writing!
   All my best to Gladys and you.  Again - thanks.

Affectionately -
Henrietta
Completed

       Hope you and Gladys like it back in Moberly.
 Sorry I didn't meet Jos. Light.  May write him - or should I, now that I'm back?
    I'm to have a reminiscence in one of Anais Nin's future diaries.
   Forgive brevity - and haste.  I, too, am in midst of chaos - precious things lost in my journeying, etc.
   Good luck to you and Gladys -

Affectionately -
Henrietta
Completed

235 W. 13 St., NY, NY  10011
Aug. 9, 1969
Dear Jack -

     Thanks a million for your letter (copy of which you sent me).  See Steig sometimes - but since he's artist (graphic - cartoons) havent asked him.  Anyway Anais Nin, Abe Rothberg (pub-writes) Elliott Schryver (now ed'l dir. for McKay), Dr. Sulzer (just retiring - had been head of Indiana U.'s Communications Dept.), and yourself underlined:  all sent letters.  So they  have more than requested.
   Forgive haste - my sister broke hip - had operation - and is in  hospital, where I rush daily.  What a summer!
   We all look forward to seeing you!  You sound fine - and busy.  Love to  you and Gladys - and, again,, dear Jack, thanks (Good luck!)

Henrietta
Completed

255-1192
underlined:  Apt. 24A - 419 W 17 St.  NYC 10011 
Nov. 24, 1971
Dear Jack -

    I do hope all is well with you and Gladys and your family.  Are you writing?
   By now you know I, too, wrote a piece about R. Wright for the forthcoming underlined:  New Letters.
   I've moved, you see -- but am trying to move again!  As soon as I can get more copies of interview (& photo) a fine young writer (I never before met) did with me, I'll send you a copy.  David Ray of underlined:  N Ls has one.  He can perhaps let you see it.

(over)
Completed

It explains why living in a public (Federal) project is even more hazardous than living - if underlined:  that is possible.
   I don't know Michel Fabré's address now in France (he's having essay - D. Ray said over phone from Mo - in the Wright issue) - if you have it his address (perhaps D. Ray has) I'd like it when  you've time.
  Forgive haste - tomorrow is Thanksgiving & tho I mock holidays, I seem enslaved by them.
  Please write when you feel like it.
  Love to you and Gladys.

Henrietta
Ironically I had a story long ago in U. of K.C. Rev. - the old name of [[underlined:  ? Letters]] - long past!
Completed

419 West 17 Street (Apt. 24A)  NY, NY  10011  (11/16/73)
Dear Jack -

    Hope all is well with you and Gladys.
    Forgive my bothering you - as I know too well how "pressured" you must be (working on your autobio, I hope it goes well).
    It has become impossible for me to stay  on in this project - jungle (having just had pleurisy - the medicos insist I must move).
    I've applied to Wesbeth - after fruitlessly apt. hunting - originally housing created for writers, artists, etc. in N.Y.C.
    Such red tape!   They request letters re. my literary talent.  (over)
Completed

should you not mind, it could be sent to me, and addressed "To Whom It may Concern," and I'll send it along to them with the application, and other reference letters.

    I write always (as you know by seeing underlined:  New Letters; they've taken 3 things of mine, so far.  The latest in Summer 1973 issue got favorably reviewed in their [[underlined:  News-Letter).
   Happy Thanksgiving!

and love to Gladys and you.
Henrietta
Completed

Nov. 27, 19973  A.M.
Dear Jack - since by now, you are in Chicago, I don't send this airmail.  My hasty note shall await you when you're back home.

   I do hope Gladys is feeling better!  I believe in acupuncture; alas, it is still illegal in this city.
   First, so many thanks for your kind wonderful reference letter.
   It's exciting news about [underlined:  The Anvil Anthology.]]   I pray it sells as it underlined:  should - I shall tell everyone about it.  It ought to do well - since underlined:  now seems a nostalgic time.  Horrible Nixon, underlined:  et al. puts this country in a 

(over)
Completed

2.
state of nightmare.

    I'm sorry about Arno Bontemps.  Always, with death of one dear, the living endure the shock of loss.
    Wish you could come to N.Y. - Tho this city, as someone disintegrating, seems to be falling apart.
    Again, dear Jack, good luck!  And thanks again - and love to Gladys and you.

Henrietta

My 8/74
Dear Jack -

   Hope all's well with you and Gladys.  Just wanted you to know that by June 1, I'll be moving to Westbeth - 463 West St., (Apt. G113) NYC. 10014.  Thank you for having helped to get me in!
    Excuse haste - much to do.  Meantime am here.  All great good luck. - Love to you & Gladys -

Henrietta
Completed

new address arrow to address   463 West Street (Apt. G-113)  New York, N.Y.  10014
Jan. 6, 1975 - Monday A.M.
Dear Jack -

      First, let me wish Gladys and you and your family a year of fulfillment and blessings.
      Forgive this tardy letter.  I'd moved  (to above address) unexpectedly, late in May 1974.   Where I am now, used to be the old 'phone bdg. - converted about 10 years ago (by a man with a dream) into studios for ptrs., scultptors, composers, writers, etc.   When he died, evidently the dream was tarnished somewhat by the real estate management that took over.  But "Westbeth" (as the bldg. that takes up a underlined:  whole block is called) is still better than most N.Y. places.  I thought I'd written you the above new address; evidently, I didn't - and your card was forwarded here.
    I'd been on the waiting list here for ages it seems - when suddenly they phoned, saying a studio for one had become available, so I rushed over, and, of course, at once took it.
    My phone is the same - underlined:  255=1192, should you come to N.Y.   My yearly visitor - pleurisy - better now - Kept me from writing sooner.

(over)
Completed

I know, I think, how you feel about Arna Bontemps, and the passing of friends.  Many of mine, too, have gone gone - leaving a nostalgic ache.
    Oh Jack, I do so want you to finish your autobiography.  It would be so very important not only to literature, but to the true history of the USA - especially at this time, when the underlined:  whole world is in chaos, our own having a "depression," underlined:  if called by other names by our corrupt politicians.  We cannot shut out the mess, but doing underlined: your thing (and think of all the writers, too, you so generously discovered, published way back, spiritually sustained, encouraged as well as your own very vital contribution to Amer. letters) underlined: is affirmation - a keeping alive the best things of our now muddled country.
    "Bambi," my story the [[underlined:  New Letters[[ published in its Summer 1973 issue, has been underlined:  listed (not reprinted) under stories of distinction in underlined:  Best Amer....Stories of 1973 Houghton-M.  1974). a prof. friend wrote me.
     I also had a poem in Dec. 1974 underlined:  Indigo - a little poetry mag. - its contents are put  on

(more)
Completed

2.
tape (or, rather, cassettes) for the blind.

    What is so good about living at "Westbeth" (tho N.Y. grows worse and worse) is the meeting of some people still dedicated to their creative work - like Ericka Duncan, who at 27 years old, has completed the 1st draft of her wonderful first novel - despite having 3 kids - and a very talented (he was born in Scotland - came here to USA as a child) sculptor-husband (he is 35).
    We feel no age-gap.
    Please be well - Gladys, you, and your family.  Ah - yes - tho only calendar time, this season is one of memories for most of us.
    Love, and may this year bring you and Gladys all that is good, joyful --

Henrietta
P.S.  I shall try to get the Dec. issue of underlined:  Amer. Libraries, as I want to read - of course - your chapter on your years with Arna Bontemps.
Completed

Dec. 21, 1976 - A.M. Tues.
Dear Jack,

     I am saddened for Gladys and you at the news about your daughter Margaret Jean Tillery.  How inadequate are words!  It is the living, enduring the loss, who suffer the anguish.
     I, too, wish we could all be together for some cheer this holiday.  Forgive this "no-card."  I have a virus, a nuisance, almost visiting me each year around this time - but the antibiotics shall cure.  But I've not been able to get out to buy the proper cards, etc.
    I hope you are working on your autobiography - difficult now, I know, but a solace, too.  And we all look forward to reading underlined:  you.
    There's little to tell - N.Y. changes (for the worst) - and tho I know people of all ages, nostalgia for a past that 

(over)
Completed

perhaps never was, at times overwhelms me - especially as the underlined:  new year approaches.

    But I write (especially poems - so man, hard to type them up, and too lazy to send them out.  I do read them sometimes at public occasions here, and to friends).  underlined:  New Letters is publishing some poems in a future issue by a 23-year old friend of mine, Andrea Goodman - a wonderful poet and writer.
    And another friend (he's in his 40's) is having a first book of poetry out;  I am among the 4 people (he asked ) who wrote a blurb - or whatever it's called, for it.
    I embrace Gladys and you - and hope soon soon we may meet.
    May the holidays be kind to you both - and the new year a better one.
    Love, and blessings, to you and Gladys.

Henrietta
